instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A2289: What is A2289? A2289 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2020 with EMC 3456, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01987..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Hello Everyone,
I have recently joined this forum. 
I have received one <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) Macbook. It shows 20 V and .079 amps on amp meter. 
I already tried DFU on the macbook but failed in between. The voltage on L7030 coil is only 10 V. Please help me to resolve the issue in that case.

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

On the new Apple boards, L7030 is not placed on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; check at F7000 instead!
Chgeck if all SSD voltages are present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Thank you 2informaticos for warm welcome and quick reply.

Here are the voltages checked on <CHIP>U8800</CHIP> chip. 

F7000                                                     12.70V
<SIGNAL>PP_SSD0_S4E2_VPP</SIGNAL>                             0.013V
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0_S4E2_VDD_PLL</SIGNAL>             0.90V
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>                            2.520V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCQ_ANI_SSD0</SIGNAL>                             1.80V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_IO_SSD0</SIGNAL>                                   1.80V
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL>                                         0.902V
<SIGNAL>SSD0_S4E2_ANI1_VREF</SIGNAL>                       0.900V
<SIGNAL>SSD0_S4E2_ANI0_VREF</SIGNAL>                       0.900V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0_S4E2_AVDD18_PLL</SIGNAL>      1.802V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0_S4E2_PCI_AVDD_H</SIGNAL>       1.804V

The error I am getting during DFU mode :  
Failed to restore device in recovery mode, libusbrestore error:21 [com.apple.MobileDevice.MobileRestore â€“ 0x15 (21)] 
Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Do you get the same message error in revive and restore?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Yes, I was getting the same error. Please suggest me any solution for this problem.
Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Any history fault available?
Did you connect the machine with correct/dedicated USB port for DFU?
Also try another cable; original Apple Thunderbolt 3 is recommended.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Okay, Thanks for suggestions. I will try and update the results.
Thanks
